Award.AwardTitle: Novel Quantitative Proteomic Methods to Discover and Localize Endogenous Protein Complexes
Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Daniel Szymanski (Purdue University)

CoPIs: Mark Hall, Daisuke Kihara, Jun Xie (Purdue University)

There is a strong need for systems-level data sets that enable a more efficient translation of basic knowledge into improved crop traits. Information on protein complex composition is one such example, but resources for crop plants are lacking. This project proposes a novel mass spectrometry-based method to solve endogenous protein complexes in soybean. The results will serve as hypothesis-generating machines for the reverse-genetic analysis of a major crop. The approach couples multiple chromatography separations of cytosolic extracts with quantitative label-free mass spectrometry of the column fractions. The relative abundance of the proteins across the purification scheme will be used to cluster co-purifying proteins into groups that reveal protein complex composition. Unlike other large-scale, protein interaction techniques, this new approach is simple to experimentally validate using existing mutant collections. This inexpensive technique does not require gene replacement technology, large-scale gene cloning, or targeted purification strategies. To establish the effectiveness of this method, the investigators will pursue three research objectives: 1) to predict and validate the composition of 100 endogenous protein complexes isolated from leaf cytosol; 2) to use bioinformatics and existing "omics" data sets to predict and evaluate models for protein complex composition; and 3) to determine if the compositions of cytosolic protein complexes are conserved in Glycine max.

Although mass spectrometry has been used extensively in proteomics research, to the investigators' knowledge the proposed strategy for large-scale protein complex prediction has not been done. Successful completion of this work will provide broadly useful results, databases, and reagents that will reveal the composition of endogenous protein complexes. This deep analysis of the cytosolic proteome will provide an important data set that enables crop scientists to further modify proteins and pathways with the goal to improve crop productivity.

The Purdue Initiative on Plant Protein Interactions (PIPPI) will provide broad impact by reaching diverse audiences through such activities as research opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students and postdoctoral fellows; and a website providing data on plant protein complexes for researchers. Students will gain skills collaborating in diverse university research environments, be exposed to cutting-edge research in plant proteomics, and develop leadership and organizational abilities by assisting with project management, research design, and data release. By partnering with various campus diversity programs and offices, all aspects of the project will involve underrepresented undergraduate and graduate students in STEM disciplines. Proteomic data sets will be available to the public at https://proteomecommons.org. It is expected that this novel project will help prepare the next generation of plant geneticists that utilize diverse types of data to drive crop improvement strategies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Modern agricultural practices and genetics have created food and fiber production capacity that can meet global needs. However, human population increases and climate instability are putting increasing strains on crop production systems. At the same time, there are new opportunities to uses plants as a renewable sources of fuel, plastics, and pharmaceuticals. Consequently, there are unprecedented opportunities to combine advanced plant breeding and biotechnology to generate the next generation of crops. These crops will have specified architectures, engineered metabolism, robust tolerances of extreme environments, and engineered resistance to pathogens.

            Successful crop engineering is a grand challenge in the life sciences. Important traits are specified by systems of genetically encoded protein circuitries. For example, the size, shape, and metabolic activity of leaves are critical traits because leaves convert sunlight into high energy sugars that fuel plant growth and development. High energy sugars are temporarily stored as oils and starch in sub-compartments within single cells. These stored energy-rich molecules can either be locally consumed during leaf growth or exported to other organs in the plant. This metabolic partitioning is controlled as a function of the growth status of the leaf and the energy demands of other parts of the plant. In this example, successful leaf engineering would require key knowledge about the proteins that control the synthesis, conversion, storage, and transport of sugars. The functional properties of dozens or hundreds of interacting proteins that control a trait are hard to discover. Although the sequence of the protein is easily determined based on the DNA sequence of the gene, its function and regulation are not.  Parameters like protein abundance, its location in the cell, how the protein is modified, and the identity of its binding partners that help it function must measured empirically.

The project developed new technologies that are able to generate functional data on thousands of proteins in a single experiment. The overall approach was to separate leaf cells into soluble and membrane-associated fractions. Based on this cell fractionation we obtained information on where in the cell the protein is likely to reside. The protein mixtures were then separated on chromatography columns under gentle conditions that do not disrupt protein complexes. Protein complexes, defined as the oligomeric structure of multiple polypeptides that physically associate with one another, are the cornerstone of biological system. Protein complexes do mechanical work, increase the efficiency of enzymatic pathways, and organize information flow and coordinate cellular activities. After the protein mixtures are separated into hundreds of different fractions based on their physical characteristics, protein mass spectrometry (proteomics) is used to measure the abundance and modifications of thousands of proteins in a single experiment. This project developed a highly reproducible quantitative proteomics pipeline to measure the localization, abundance, oligomerization state, and protein complex composition of thousands of proteins and hundreds of protein complexes. These large databases are providing useful data on how protein pathways are localized and regulated in the cell. Our data have been made available to the public as supplemental data in our publications. The methods and computer code to generate and analyze the data have also been made freely available. Our data are being used by the research community to discover and manipulate intracellular control pathways that impact important crop traits. We also expect scientists in the fields of network biology and computational modeling to use our data to generate systems-level models for metabolic and signaling pathways. We expect to publish three additional papers. One uses our methods to predict the composition of protein complexes. Another, uses our methods to analyze how proteins and protein complexes change in response to metabolic stress. A third compares protein complex assembly in Arabidopsis, soybean, developing rice seeds, and cotton fibers. Collectively these papers and our published work will provide large mechanistic datasets that will broadly accelerate protein function discovery and help to provide the baseline knowledge that is needed to engineer plants with improved tolerance to environmental stress.

This is an interdisciplinary project that has was developed using the model plant Arabidopsis and has been successful adapted to diverse crops and tissue types. In the future, we expect this technology further in crops species. This is an interdisciplinary project that combined plant physiology, analytical chemistry, novel statistical analyses, and bioinformatics. As a result  the project provided an opportunity for  cross-training and broad learning among the entire scientific team. A post-doctoral fellow affiliated with the project is now the director of a major proteomics core facility. Two graduate students will earn their PhDs because of the support from this award, and both are pursuing careers in the life sciences. Two undergraduate researchers participated in the research, and both are authors on peer-reviewed publications.
